prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA Left my kid in the school and waited in the parking lot to scare him:
Left my kid in the school and waited in the parking lot to scare him:

8 year old kid. Has parent teacher conferences. Prior the the conferences he is freaking out about something (to my wife while I'm not there). During the conferences he gets a less than stellar report. He has good grades and all, but a lot of shouting/acting up in class. So after the conference he wants to buy a book from the library book store. My wife hesitates, and I drop a firm "No". He starts to get huffy and says hes going into the library book fair anyways, which he does.

I tell my wife lets just keep walking. So we walk out to the car, I put the three younger kids in, and my wife takes them home. She thinks I am going back in to get him. I stay in my car, which is in direct view of the exit of the school. I wait for him to come out which happens in about 20 minutes.

He comes out in a panic, crying, thinking we left him.

My wife is angry that I did not go into the school to get him, and that I instead led him to believe that we left him at the school.

I will update with any follow up/ or clarifying answers.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. So the situation is about a parent (the author) who left their 8-year-old child at school during a book fair incident. They had parent-teacher conferences, and the kid was acting out. After the conference, the kid wanted to buy a book, but the parent said no. The kid went in anyway, and the parents left, thinking they'd come back later. The mom took the younger kids home, assuming the dad would get the kid. But the dad stayed in the car, waiting for the kid to come out, and the kid ended up crying, thinking they left him.

Hmm. The key points here are the parent's decision to not go in and wait in the car instead of retrieving the kid. The child is 8, which is pretty young. The parent's intention was to scare the child, maybe to teach a lesson about disobeying. But the child ended up being left alone for 20 minutes, which could be traumatic. The other parent (wife) is upset because she thought the husband would go in and get him, but he didn't. 

I need to assess if the parent was wrong. The parent's action led the child to believe they were abandoned, which is a serious emotional issue. Even if the intention was disciplinary, leaving a child alone for that long without checking in could be neglectful. Also, the parent didn't go into the school, which might have been the safer option. Instead, they stayed in the car, possibly out of sight, which made the child panic. There's a lack of communication between the parents as well; the wife assumed the husband would go in, which he didn't. 

The child was upset and crying, which shows the emotional impact. While the parent might have thought it was a way to teach a lesson, the method could be seen as cruel or neglectful. The parent didn't take responsibility for ensuring the child's emotional well-being in that situation. So, considering all that, the parent is likely in the wrong because they intentionally left the child in a distressing situation without immediate intervention, leading to the child feeling abandoned. The answer should be A.
